pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [5dbb0cb05a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13653/commits/5dbb0cb05ab4bd6d09c38c2d79c68267e6670499)

Import changes exceeding 2%

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +12.90% | `Mathlib.Tactic.Linter` |

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic.Linter | 31 | 35 | +4 (+12.90%) |
| Mathlib.Order.Category.BoolAlg | 443 | 445 | +2 (+0.45%) |
| Mathlib.Order.Category.FinBddDistLat | 614 | 616 | +2 (+0.33%) |
| Mathlib.Order.Category.FinBoolAlg | 628 | 630 | +2 (+0.32%) |
| Mathlib.Topology.Separation.Regular | 678 | 680 | +2 (+0.29%) |
| Mathlib.NumberTheory.FactorisationProperties | 790 | 792 | +2 (+0.25%) |
| Mathlib.RingTheory.TensorProduct.Basic | 990 | 992 | +2 (+0.20%) |
| Mathlib.Algebra.Category.Ring.Adjunctions | 1116 | 1118 | +2 (+0.18%) |
| Mathlib.Algebra.Homology.HomotopyCategory.Triangulated | 1222 | 1224 | +2 (+0.16%) |
| Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.BinaryEntropy | 1809 | 1811 | +2 (+0.11%) |
| Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2 | 1891 | 1893 | +2 (+0.11%) |
| Mathlib.Tactic | 2606 | 2608 | +2 (+0.08%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 5167 files with changed transitive imports taking up over 222478 characters: this is too many to display!
You can run `scripts/import_trans_difference.sh all` locally to see the whole output.

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ bar`
`+ d1`
`+ findSetOptionIn`
`+ foo`
`+ foo'`
`+ foo''`
`+ instance (priority := high) : Inhabited Nat := ⟨0⟩`
`+ instance (priority := high) d : Inhabited Nat := ⟨0⟩`
`+ instance (priority := high) e : Inhabited Nat := ⟨0⟩`
`+ instance : Inhabited Nat := ⟨0⟩`
`+ toExample`
`+ unnecessarySetOptionIn`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>Decrease in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (4.00, 1.04)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|96|-4|adaptation notes|
|4|-4|maxHeartBeats modifications|

Current commit [5dbb0cb05a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/5dbb0cb05ab4bd6d09c38c2d79c68267e6670499)
Reference commit [7b4a09d210](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/7b4a09d2102c2eae2457af54dfcb57a51e99c5e0)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

The linter error in `Mathlib/Order/LiminfLimsup.lean:1331` is a false positive: with removing the set_option, compilation succeeds, but with a *warning*. (By the way, this could be another nice test case: checking e.g. that in a lemma using a deprecated declaration, the `set_option linter.deprecated false in` is not considered superfluous.)

Another observation: the linter does not lint the `set_option genSizeOfSpec false in` in `SetTheory/Ordinal/Notation.lean`.
Removing that and running #lint seems to work... but perhaps that's a different class of issue than what this linter is for!

Great idea! I know this is in draft status - I took a look anyway (and hope you don't mind).
I have a few suggestions for the docs (see below). I also wonder if "unnecessarySetOptionIn" would be a better name - since you're not checking if the option *never influences* elaboration, but merely if *things work without*.
I ended up going for your version: the reason behind what I had, was that I was intepreting the `example` as a `Name`, but it does not matter much either way -- it is a syntax node anyway!
how about "... against outer-most `set option ... in`s which are not necessary"?
Also overhauled by the new docs on the linter.
Yes, I should have recycled this using `inherit_doc`.

How about this tweak?
"Report a warning if a `set_option ... in` command is unnecessary (i.e., the code elaborates fine without).
We only report the outermost `set_option ... in` (i.e., superfluous `set_option ... in`s which are nested are not linted against)."

If you'd like, you could also add
- why is not reporting on nested superfluous set_option in is not not so bad (is this just for simplicity, as the linter can be run multiple times? that's probably fine!)
- add one sentence why this is bad: for instance, might distract or confuse --- if this option was for backwards incompatibility, the fact that it can be removed now is a useful signal.

The new doc-string is (once I will push)
```
Report a warning if a `set_option ... in` command is unnecessary
(i.e., the code elaborates fine without it).
We only report the outermost `set_option ... in` (i.e., nested, superfluous `set_option ... in`s
are not linted against).

This is useful since unnecessary `set_option ... in`s are often silent left-overs of adaptations
that are no longer needed.
Cleaning them up, helps maintaining healthy, up-to-date code.

The linter runs just on the outermost `set_option ... in` mostly for simplicity.
Consider whether emitting a warning if one of the nested `set_option ... in`s can be omitted,
by removing them one at a time.
```

Do you want to differentiate which option is set? For instance, if I set `profiler.threshold 50 in`, I want to have this for temporary purposes - and linting on it seems more dubious than useful.
(The `set_option` linter also covers that case - written in Python, but its rewrite in Lean is awaiting review.)

I was planning to discriminate on which option is being set by going over what the linter flags.  For instance, I am not sure whether this linter should handle various thresholds/heartbeats, since maybe a more dedicated one could also do some diagnostics on the side.

pullRequest.title: feat: the unusedSetOptionIn linter

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: remove some `set_option ... in` which are not necessary any more
[Merged by Bors] - chore: remove unnecessary term or tactic `set_option in` with backwards-compatibility flags
[Merged by Bors] - chore: remove unused `set_option in`
[Merged by Bors] - chore: add comment to a borderline `set_option maxHeartbeats`
